dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General atmosphere, typical of a busy  newspaper office. Copy boys running  about, shirtsleeved reporters and rewrite  men pounding away on typewriters. Little  wire baskets containing cylinders of  copy whizzing back and forth, such as  are used in some department stores,  etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Morkrum machines,[1] typewriters, telephone  bells and all other sounds relative  to a newspaper office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When shot has been fully established:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes in the battery of Morkrum machines  clattering away; the crescent-shaped  copy desk; the desk of the sporting  editor, with a big cauliflower-eared  pugilist and his manager standing by  the side of the sporting editor, a hefty  guy in his shirtsleeves, smoking a big  cigar and wearing a green eye-shade;  the desk of the society editor, a prissy  old lady, who takes down a worn copy  of the Blue Book as the camera passes  her and starts looking up some data;  and any other interesting or typical  bits that can be thought out. At the  far end of the room is the desk of Conroy,  the City Editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything shows evidence of feverish  activity and great haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Conroy, the City Editor at his desk,  speaking on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's all I ever get from you  guys - a lot of hard luck stories. You  come back here and I'll give you an  assignment. It will be a last interview  - with the cashier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, looks around with a scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr. Conroy, give me a crack at that  Schuyler story, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? If you ever got your foot into  a drawing room, you'd step on a sliding  rug! Stew is the only man that's got  brains enough to handle this. Scram!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Copy Boy rushes by on an errand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Spud, did you find Stew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did you look in theВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not there, eh? For cryin' out loud,  where is thatВ—? Go and dig him up! Stew!  Stew Smith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until it takes in a sort of make-shift  screen, concealing a corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the screen. Stew  Smith is holding something in his hand.  His hat tilted back on his head, and  he is regarding this plaything intently.  Gallagher is sitting close to him, also  gazing intently at the plaything. Gallagher  is a girl, one of the sob sisters[2]  on the newspaper, dressed in a trim  but inexpensive little tailored suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is. Pray for me, Gallagher.  Pray for me. Hold everything . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the object in his hand, one of those  hand-puzzles where you have to land  jumping beans in the holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, your hands are shaking. You've  been drinking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. Here they come, Gallagher!  Here they come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy's shouts are heard in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the third one. If I don't get  the last one, there's a certain sob  sister I know that's going to get a  kick right in the . . . oh! Whoops,  almost had that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy, the City Editor at his desk,  looking about with a scowl for Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Copy Boy races over to whisper something  to Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen, concealing the washbasin  corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wrathy Conroy, his eyes centering  suspiciously on something. With his  eyes on the screen, Conroy reaches out  and grasps a heavy telephone book on  the corner of his desk. Still looking  off, he heaves it forcefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing the screen. The telephone book  crashes into it, overturning it and  revealing Stew and Gallagher on the  other side. They both look up, startled.  The newsroom erupts in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy at his desk. Stew saunters into  the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always picking on me. It took  me three hours to get those little gadgets  in those holes, and you screw it up  in a minute. Hey, look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the hand-puzzle to Conroy,  who is immediately captivated by the  fascinating object in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, not as easy as it looks, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy puts it down with a disgusted  look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aagh! No wonder you're batty. Would  it be imposing too much upon you if  I asked you to do a little work today?  Just to sort of break the monotony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With me you can always do business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what to do in a drawing-room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a question of knowing what  to do, it's knowing how to get in one  that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings, Conroy answers  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, turns back to Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, we've got a tip that the  Schuyler family has finally made a deal  with that chorus dame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The human cash register. Got her hooks  into the Schuyler kid, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right - for the first time this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, get going, get going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get going where? I can write that yarn  without stepping out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - and get us into a million dollar  libel suit. It wouldn't be the first  time. Now, you get over there and get  a statement out of the old lady, the  sister, or the kid. Any of them - but  get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Give me a voucher for expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What expenses? All you need is carfare  to Long Island. You'd better get a shave  and a shine, because you, you're going  to have a tough time getting in there  as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know those bluenoses. Their ancestors  refused to come over on the Mayflower  because they didn't want to rub elbows  with the tourists. So they swam over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13. EXT. THE SCHUYLER HOUSE - DAY -  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone pacing outside the mansion gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14. EXT. THE SCHUYLER HOUSE (ANOTHER  ANGLE) - DAY - CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard dog pacing inside the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15. INT. INSIDE THE MANSION - DAY -  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parrot on its perch, hopping from  foot to foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16. INT. SCHUYLER DRAWING ROOM - DAY  - CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Schuyler, a callow youth with  the usual dissipated, spoiled look.  His fingers are nipping out little chunks  of a folded piece of paper, dropping  the bits on the floor. This is indicative  of a habit of the individual in question  when undergoing nervous stress. He is  very fidgety and apprehensive, as he  glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Schuyler, a beautiful and aristocratic,  though slightly hard girl, a few years  older than Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Stuyvesand Van Alstyne Schuyler,  mother of Anne and Michael. A grande  dame, stern and glowering. Her attitude  indicates suppressed nervousness and  anger. She glares over in the direction  of Michael. Then she turns and looks  in another direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter Grayson, if you were any kind  of a lawyer, you'd get those letters  back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter Grayson, the family lawyer standing,  his hands clasped behind his back, just  completing the pacing of a few short  steps in his best courtroom manner,  his head bowed in an attitude of deepest  thought. He is dressed in striped afternoon  trousers and black coat. He turns to  regard Mrs. Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I keep telling you how difficult  it is, Mrs. Schuyler. The last time  I asked her for those letters, she made  very uncouth noises with her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Schuyler, trying desperately to  keep from laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To reveal a full shot of the room and  group. They are in the magnificent drawing  room of the Schuyler home, resembling  the Union Depot and furnished with almost  imperial splendor and magnificence.  They very much resemble a jury in session.  As they continue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're making all this  fuss. I only sent her six of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had to make a fool of yourself,  why didn't you tell it to her instead  of writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I couldn't get her on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have known better than to  write, Romeo. I found that out a long  time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should say you had. At the rate you  two are going, we'll have to leave the  country to save our faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid, Mother. Let's hop over to  Monte Carlo. It's a great place to save  a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A butler appears in the doorway. He  is about to say something, but he stammers  and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, madam - but what am I to  say to the newspapermen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler looks distractedly at  Grayson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler and Grayson. She rises  and speaks imperiously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter, go out and tell those ruffians  I have nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that. Leave it to me. I  know how to handle reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then - get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson turns officiously toward the  waiting butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've decided to see the reporters.  Send in the man from the Tribune first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Smythe, some bicarbonate of soda,  quick - double strength. I know those  news mongrels[3] will upset me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've anticipated it, madame. The bicarbonate  is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19. INT. SCHUYLER LIBRARY - DAY - FULL  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room resembles the Grand Central  Station. It is lined with bookcases  filled with gorgeous first editions  and special bindings, and is furnished  in the extreme of magnificence and luxury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present are Stew and Bingy, reporter  from the Tribune. Stew is seated, idly  leafing through a first edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy, still with his hat on, spots  an expensive music box on a nearby table,  opens it and does a little jig to the  tune that is emitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy, as he lingers at the table. He  is a lazy, sloppy-looking guy. His face  needs a shave and his pants need pressing.  There is a spot of dried ketchup on  his tie. On the table is a humidor.  Bingy opens it and lifts out a handful  of cigars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks up from the book, he suggests:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Bingy, you'll find the silverware  in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy turns, putting the cigars in his  pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Grayson has decided to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Stew and Bingy start forward eagerly.  Smythe continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentleman from the Tribune, first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy beams broadly and Stew is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no gentlemen on the Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe leads the way out. As Bingy passes  by, Stew trips him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, take it easy! Take it easy! Listen,  my boy. No use you hanging around here.  Just buy the Tribune tonight and read  all about it. You can rewrite it for  your last edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't make the last edition. It'd  take me four hours to translate your  story into English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your hat. You might make an  impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, make up your mind, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy hurriedly puts his hat back on  as he disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24. INT. SCHUYLER DRAWING ROOM - DAY  - MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the door which leads out into the  hall. The butler enters and stops, standing  stiffly. Bingy enters behind him, shambling  awkwardly. He stops in some consternation  as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Schuyler jury. Grayson, Mrs. Schuyler,  Anne and Michael, all surveying him  in varying degrees of unfriendliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy hesitates uneasily as he regards  this impressive assemblage. Quickly,  he takes his hat back off. Then he smiles  nervously and starts forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson comes forward to meet him, attempting  to be very cordial. Bingy is seized  by a sudden impulse to sneeze. He does  so, violently. There is awkward silence.  Mrs. Schuyler throws off a visible shudder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Isn't there a 'bless  you' in the crowd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy extends his hand. Grayson pointedly  ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy crosses the room, taking note  of the beauteous Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy sits gingerly on the edge of a  handsome chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy and Grayson. Grayson picks up  a very flossy and expensive cigarette  box from the small end table beside  the chair. It is made of gold and semi-precious  stones are inset in the cover. Grayson  opens the lid and takes out a cigarette,  but pointedly does not offer one to  Bingy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson remains standing before the  reporter, who is very uncomfortable  and ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew your managing editor very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clears her throat menacingly, as  she looks sternly at Grayson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? She got a cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy and Grayson. Both look over. Grayson  gives her a quick reassuring glance,  as though to say "leave it to me now."  He continues his conversation with the  reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got him his job on the paper. I'm  a stock-holder, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one Tribune man to anotherВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But right now I'm acting in the capacity  of Mrs. Schuyler's attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right with me. I won't  hold it against you. But you see, I'm  here to find out aboutВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. But there's no truth  in the story whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson and Bingy. He takes Bingy by  the arm and leads him over to a corner  of the room, assuming a confidential  pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, I've taken the trouble to prepare  a little statement. Here it is. Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson and Bingy. Grayson takes an  envelope out of his pocket and hands  it to Bingy. Bingy opens the flap and  sees the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corner of a fifty dollar bill protrudes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy quickly shuts the envelope up.  Grayson is watching him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you see how silly that rumor is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, sure. It's a lotta hooey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted to say, but I couldn't  think of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson starts leading him toward the  door. CAMERA PANS WITH THEM as Grayson  leads him toward the door, talking as  they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right, don't mention  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give my regards to your managing editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at the door. Bingy extends  a handshake, which is again refused.  He stops and looks back at the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Schuylers all sitting silently and  contemplating him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flutters his eyes at Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one last look at Mrs. Schuyler  and is again gripped by a violent sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler appears in the doorway behind  him. Bingy exits past him, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, bring in the other reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31. INT. SCHUYLER DRAWING ROOM - MEDIUM  FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group awaiting the advent of the  Post reporter. Stew is shown in by the  butler, still carrying the Conrad book  in his hand. They give him the once-over.  Mrs. Schuyler raises her lorgnette with  a magnificent gesture. Stew eyes them  with animation, not in the slightest  discouraged by this supercilious scrutiny.  He starts toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schuyler's the name, I presume? Yes,  thank you, thank you. My name's Smith  - Stewart Smith. No relation to John,  Joe, Trade or Mark. Of course you can't  have everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles engagingly on them. Stew addresses  Mrs. Schuyler ingratiatingly, disregarding  her expression of obvious distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice set of Conrads you have out there,  Mrs. Schuyler. I was just glancing through  this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Michael tearing the paper about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a habit. Mr. Schuyler is a bit  put out by all the rumors going around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumors? Rumors? Since when is a breach-of-promise  case a rumor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No breach-of-promise case has been filed.  The matter has been settled out of court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I see, but Gloria doesn't seem to  be satisfied with the twenty thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this, Mrs. Schuyler rises wrathfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter Grayson, you told me it was only  ten thousandВ—and you didn't even get  those letters from that Jezebel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so you did give her ten thousand  dollars, eh? and there are letters .  . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Stew's back, Grayson makes violent  gestures for her to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. That takes it out of the  rumor class, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We admit nothing. However, I have a  little statement all prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Stew's arm and walks him off  toward a corner much in the same manner  as he handled Bingy, and lowers his  voice confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson takes an envelope out of his  pocket and hands it to Stew. Stew puts  the book under his arm, takes the envelope  and extracts the contents. It is another  greenback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He regards it a moment, then replaces  the bill in the envelope. His voice  is matter-of-fact, and almost casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know you should never offer  a newspaper man more than two dollars?  If you do, he'll think it's counterfeit.  I don't need fifty dollars. As a matter  of fact, I've got fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson is considerably disconcerted.  He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man from the Tribune seemed perfectly  satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Bingy? Yeah, Bingy would. He never  saw fifty dollars before. You could  have bought him for six bits. Funny  thing about Bingy. The more he gets  - the more he prints. He looks stupid,  doesn't he? But oh how smart he gets  when he bends over a typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the envelope back to Grayson  and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schuyler group - taking his action with  dismay. Stew starts walking back toward  them, talking as he walks, Grayson beside  him, considerably distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ten grand was the amount you gave  the girl? Any other statement you folks  would like to make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an explosive chorus from the  group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have nothing more to say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to them, holding up his hand  and speaking plaintively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Don't get excited. I  wouldn't worry about it. A little publicity  never hurt anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is on the point of an apopletic  stroke. She advances menacingly toward  Stew. She calls to Grayson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter, have this person leave immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is not at all perturbed. Dexter  takes him by the arm and starts to lead  him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go?! Wait a minute - that's a great  story! Newspaper reporter was forcibly  ejected from Schuyler Mansion, andВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He faces her and cannot help but register  an appreciation of her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind her if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler, almost choking in her  wrath at this outrageous stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne stifles a smile at this cheerful  insolence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're quite willing to be  decent about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decent? Why Miss Schuyler, I want to  be noble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne continues in her most devastating  manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to print this silly  thing, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand lightly on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my name's Schuyler too. And  I haven't done a thing, but I'll suffer  with Michael. And so will Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been listening to this and enjoying  it immensely. He looks over at Mrs.  Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is making a show of holding back  a flood of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, not wanting to lose her point,  looks up at Stew pleadingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a special favor to me, you won't  print that story, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, looking down at her in frank approval  and admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler, Michael, and Grayson.  All watching the couple intently, hanging  on the next wordsВ—wondering if Anne  is going to succeed. They are tense  and expectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking down into her soft, melting  eyes. Then he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, lady, if you sold  life insurance, I'd go for a policy  in sixty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, I knew you'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three. They relax and exchange relieved  and triumphant glances. Apparently Anne  has won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She indicates. Stew starts for the telephone.  Anne walks to her mother's side. Stew  gets to the telephone and picks up the  receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he turns to wink at the group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an unlucky number. You know that,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the telephone. He turns back to the  instrument as he gets his connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Toots? Is Conroy there? Give  me Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't? Try the washroom, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he waits for the connection, he  turns and addresses the group expansively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I interviewed a swell guy the other  day - Einstein. Swell guy, a little  eccentric, but swell. Doesn't wear any  garters. Neither do I as a matter of  fact. What good are garters anywayВ—?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Conroy? This is Smith talking.  I'm up at the Schuylers. No, I'm not  having tea - that is, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, he winks expansively at the  groupВ—then returns to Conroy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she beautiful? Oh boss, her pictures  don't do her justice. If I was that  guy Ziegfield - what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46. CLOSE SHOT - ANNE AND MRS. SCHUYLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne smiles in spite of herself at this  flattery. Stew's voice goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's easy to see where her beauty  comes from. From her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Mrs. Schuyler unbends  to the extent of giving forth a smile.  She cannot help but be pleased at this  compliment. The atmosphere is now very  friendly. Everybody feels that everything  is all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. Just hold on. Keep  your shirt on. I'm coming to that. The  Schuylers admit the story is true. Right.  They gave the gal ten thousand bucks.  But she's got some letters - and she's  holding out for more dough - and it  looks to me like she's going to get  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified and shocked at this betrayal  and double-crossing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right boss. I'll be right over. Right  - no, I don't think I can get any pictures  now. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casually hangs up and turns from  the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne confronts him as if he were a reptile  of the lowest order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've met some rotters in my time, but  without a doubt, you're the lowest excuse  for a man I've ever had the misfortune  to meetВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew starts walking toward the door,  still holding his book. The family is  tremendously indignant and agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew stops, turns, looks at them. He  is met by icy glares. He indignantly  takes a nickel out of his pocket and  hands it to Grayson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you feel that way about it,  here's a nickel for the phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glares at themВ—turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch him walk out, stunned and  open-mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Dingy board sign outside a building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Three column heading in newspaper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reasonably respectable speakeasy,  smoke-filled. Quite a number of men  and a few women are leaning on the bar  and seated around at the tables. Stew  and Gallagher are seated at one of the  rude round tables, smoking, drinks before  them. Gallagher is reading the newspaper  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is grinning at the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and she walked up to me and put her  hand on my shoulder and said,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Mr. Smith, You wouldn't print that  story, would you?' Oh no, I wouldn't  print it - read it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Stew's shoulder. She laughs at  his attempted imitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure going to be poison to that  Junior Leaguer[4] from now on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not . . . I've got to call on  her this morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I must drop in on the mad wench.  Her wounds need soothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, Stew, are you completely  bats? What for? I thought the story  was cold. You can't go back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, the story is cold, but I'm not.  I'm sizzling - look! Psst!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moistens a finger, touches it to  his wrist, and makes a sizzle noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher looks over quizzicallyВ—a little  suspiciousВ—a little jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-o-oh! Came the dawn, came the dawn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with it came love! Oh Gallagher,  you've got to meet her. She's itВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher takes a sip of her drink before  answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've seen her pictures, and I  don't think she's so hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't appreciate it. Her pictures  don't do her justice. Why, Gallagher,  she's queenly - she is queenly - and  I know queens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And oh, has she got herself a nose -  and I know noses too. That little snozzle  of hers is the berries, I tell you.  And is she cute when she throws that  little snozzle to the high heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I haven't got a nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gives her a hurt look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. You've got a nose, Gallagher.  You've got a nose. But there's different  women, Gallagher. You know, like brewery  horses and thoroughbreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On now, Stew, don't be too hard on her.  I wouldn't call her a brewery horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the rest of us are truck horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, talking like a woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're my pal, aren't you? Then  don't turn female on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During these last few speeches, Gallagher  has been regarding him with a curious  expression. She loves being his pal,  but wishes he would realize she is also  a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew seems a little resentful of her  attitude. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay that check, will you Gallagher?  I'll give it back to you some time.  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flourishes the book of Conrad, which  has been lying on the table in front  of him, and makes a grand gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go now - I go with Conrad in quest  of my youth! Fry those tomatoes, will  you, Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, sits, looking after him,  considerably disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her bag and takes out a mirror,  surveying herself with frank disapproval.  She pulls out a curl of hair before  each ear, tries to soften the severe  brim of the hat. She puts a finger to  the tip of her nose and tilts it up,  studying the effect. Then, with a sigh  of disgust, she throws mirror and bag  onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55. INT. SCHUYLER ENTRANCE HALL - DAY  - LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, the butler, previously introduced,  comes from the direction of the rear  of the house, and proceeds down the  long, vast hallway towards the front  door. The bell keeps ringing steadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler reaches the wide front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the butler opens the door and reveals  Stew standing outside, hatless, a book  in his hand, a spring overcoat slightly  askew, the pockets bulging with contents.  The butler quickly tries to slam the  door in Stew's face, but Stew's right  foot comes forward with a practiced  newspaperman's gesture and he forces  his way into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now Jeeves.[5] Was that nice? Was  that being a gentleman, Jeeves? Was  it, Jeeves? Your name is Jeeves, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe! Well, well, well! With a Y ,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations! What a small world.  Brothers under livery. Shake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, as a Smith to a SmytheВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler is not at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. I waited outside till  she went out. She's a very nice lady,  but we don't vibrate well together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, dressed in smart sports clothes,  starts to cross thru the hall. She stops  as she sees the butler engaged in conversation  with Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne starts walking toward them. Stew  spots her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Jeeves, what would you call this  - 'no one'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks up and sees that the butler  is frowning and uncomfortable and addresses  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler left orders, Miss, that  if this person came here again, I was  to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea - telephone the police.  The number is Spring 3100. Get a couple  of cops over and we can have a rubber  of bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the lady said you may goВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler bows stiffly and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I tell you, yesterday when I was  here, I had one of your books in my  hand, and when I got outside, I realized  I still had your book in my hand. So  as long as I had your book in my hand,  I thought I might as well take it home  and read it. This morning, I got up  and put your book in my hand, and here's  your book in your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends the Conrad book, and Anne,  making no effort to take it, he throws  it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was considerate of me. I  recommend you read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in your literary  recommendations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it's a bit heavy for you.  Perhaps if you'd like something lighter  - something with a touch of romanceВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a package of letters out of  his overcoat pocket held together by  a rubber band. He extracts one of them  and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does her miss her Baby? Him sends his  booful li'l sweetums a billion oceans  full of kisses. Bobo is so lonelyВ—!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment. I don't see how that  trash could possibly concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew advances a little closer, putting  up a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! But you don't know who Bobo is.  And you don't know who Babykins is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested. Smythe will open  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Bobo is your brother, Michael. And  of course nobody would ever guess who  Babykins is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne turns and stares at him, incredulously,  for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get those letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole them when I was interviewing  Babykins about Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you're going to print them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne surveys him with frank scorn and  dislike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't need another guess. It's  quite obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you step into the library?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne walks majestically with head held  highВ—thru the hallВ—thru the living room  and to the library. CAMERA TRUCKING  AHEAD OF THEM. This is a very long walk  with Anne walking ahead, Stew trailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the Indians used to walk like  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except the squaw always walked in the  backВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why that was? That was in case  of attack from the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, if the attack was from the  rear, she had to depend upon her papoose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, the papooses always had bows  and arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, if she wasn't marriedВ—then  she'd have to protect her own - er,  erВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What country is this library in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Schuyler, how about carfare back  to the front door, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sweeps in, followed by Stew. She  walks directly to a desk, opens a drawer  and takes out a large check book. She  draws up a chair and seats herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne at the desk, starting to fill in  the date on a blank check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your initials - Mr. - erВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who has remained standing. He is watching  her with a peculiar expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith. Stewart Smith. My friends call  me Stew. It's an injustice too because  I hold my liquor all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne writes on the check. Then she looks  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will - uh - five thousand be enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew walks closer and addreses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, you shouldn't do that, Miss Schuyler.  That's all right for your lawyer friend,  but you shouldn't go around thinking  you can buy people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne has been listening to him with  a puzzled expression, impressed by his  obvious sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to thank you. Mother'll  be so grateful - she'll probably want  to kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother will want to kiss me? Give  me back my letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the breaks I get. It's the mothers  that are always grateful to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile, he hands the letters  back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a peculiar person. Why the other  day I pleaded with you not to send in  that story and В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but that was news. This is blackmail  and I don't like blackmail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is regarding him with searching  scrutiny. She smiles. Her icy, belligerent  attitude has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't even pretend it isn't a very  great favor. I wish there was something  I could do for youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you could make this table a little  - uh - a little less wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something you can do for me,  Miss Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile goes out of Anne's eyesВ—the  suspicion returnsВ—she is saying to herselfВ—"I  was right the first time!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't had any lunch yet. Have you  got anything in the icebox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hard, disdainful look leaves Anne's  face as she stares at this incredible  guy with his incredible request. With  a twinkle in her eyes, she responds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovely, sunny room, cretonne drapes  and colorful painted furniture. Stew  and Anne are sitting at the table. Anne  looks amused and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: definitely speculative. Stew has the  manner of having lived in this house  all his life. He draws the cup of tea  to him and puts in a lump or two of  sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between him and Anne on the corner of  the table is a modernistic, squatty  little tea-pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After years of research, I finally discovered  that I was the only guy in the world  who hadn't written a play, so believe  it or not, in my spare time I'm now  writing a play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I haven't figured out the plot  yet, but it's laid in a Siberian village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a bit eccentric, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? No - most ordinary guy in the world,  me. Only one thing wrong with meВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew helps himself to another lump of  sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, that's just a symbol of my independence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans closer, looking directly into  her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm color blind. That's what's wrong  - I'm color blind. I've been sitting  here for a half hour looking at you  and I don't know yet whether your eyes  are blue or violet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne smiles at this unexpected statement,  and stares at him very critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just beginning to believe that something  could be done with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you could do anything with me you  wanted to. Putty - just putty, that's  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now getting back to those eyes of yours  - would you mind if I kind of got closer  so I could see them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you're going to lose any sleep  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets closer, takes her chin in his  hand and gets an eyeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, how would you like themВ—open like  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something tells me I'd better leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the last speech Mrs. Schuyler  enters and stops in the doorway, surveying  this astonishing scene with stupefied  indignation and rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne gets quickly to her feet as Mrs.  Schuyler sails forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello - hello, Mrs. Schuyler. Come right  in. Will you have a slug of tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hospitably indicates the table. Mrs.  Schuyler is speechless with fury. She  does not immediately reply. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this person doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I was just trying  to decide the color of Anne's eyes.  I can't tell whether they're blue, or  whether they're violet. What would you  say, Mrs. Schuyler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say it, Mother, please. Mr. Smith  came here today to do us a great favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, Mrs. Schuyler and Stew. Mrs. Schuyler,  with an effort, restraining her impulse  to yank Stew out by the collar, speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed? Perhaps he will do me a great  favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. It's all right, Anne.  I can take a hint. A bit subtle, but  I get it. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please go. I'll explain to Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps close to Mrs. Schuyler's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew starts to the door, smiles at Anne,  and remarks to Mrs. Schuyler as he passes  her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come over and see us sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler freezes in inarticulate  anger, as Stew gives a courtly bow and  exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne in a stunning evening dress is  seated, a cocktail in one hand, cigarette  in the other. Dexter Grayson, in evening  clothes, is standing before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a faraway, speculative look  in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Stew and I went for a long ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter, is there any finishing school  we can send him to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the same, he's going to be a different  person when I get through with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson. He is looking at her, deeply  disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get through with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it'll be a very interesting experiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make a gentleman out of a tramp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Anne, you remember how much it  cost to get rid of that baseball player?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't seem to understand that this  one's different. He has brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson seats himself beside her on  the divan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him coldly with almost  an expression of dislike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? Oh, don't go serious on me, Dexter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elaborate, modernistic roof apartment,  thronged with people all in evening  dress. Stew and Anne are walking down  among them. Anne is radiant, and Stew  is happily guiding her among the stuffed  shirts. Anne stops before a group. There  is the sound of conversation, laughter,  clink of glasses, music from stringed  invisible orchestra, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Natalie. Mr. Stewart Smith .  . . Miss Montgomery, Mrs. Eames, Mrs.  Radcliff, Mr. RadcliffВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing, helping himself to a cocktail,  which a footman is passing about. Dexter  looks off with a frown of disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are looking off in Anne's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if these old ears don't deceive  me, I believe his name is Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith! Can't be one of the brothers  - he hasn't a beard on.[6]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he must have something if Anne  has got her clutches on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of a piano chord  being struck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Baxter, the hostess, is standing  importantly by the grand piano at which  is seated an anaemic-looking young man.  Beside her stands a stout, swarthy Italian  with bristling mustachios. Mrs. Baxter  bows toward the swarthy one, who bends  almost double in acknowledgement. There  is a polite scattering of applause,  and some of the guests seat themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unnoticed by the rest, Stew and Anne  slip out of the door into the roof garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A most beautiful, romantic spot. Rose  trees in blossom, a vine-covered pergola,  a splashing fountain, a few choice marble  statues, low, deep chairs placed to  make a gorgeous spot. Stew and Anne  enter from the direction of the house.  The garden is dark except for the lights  from the interior of the house. From  within, comes the voice of the singer  rendering an extremely romantic, sentimental  Italian love song. This will continue  to the FADE OUT of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew and Anne walk, still hand in hand,  toward the edge of the pergola where  the shadows are deeper and where a couple  of glorified steamer chairs are placed.  There is a full moon overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him toward a waterfall effect,  a glass partition down which water trickles.  They go behind the dimly lit fountain  and sit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a low, deep divan. We see them in  silhouette as they go into a passionate  embrace. All we hear is the faint voice  of MartiniВ—and the uninterrupted splashing  of the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On divan, arms around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, pinch me, will you? Throw me out  of here. Give me the air. Throw me out  of this joint, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne smiles happily and pinches his  nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I? We're happy, aren't we,  darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw me out - because I'm beginning  to get goofy ideas, and they concern  you, Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your ideas can be goofy, Stew,  if they concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Smith - well, that you seem  to have been able to stand for the last  month. I'm white, male and over twenty-one.  I've never been in jail - that is, not  often. And I prefer Scotch to Bourbon.  I hate carrots, I hate peas, I like  black coffee and I hate garters. I make  seventy-five bucks a week and I've got  eight hundred and forty-seven bucks  in the bank - and - I don't know yet  whether your eyes are blue or violet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (although he is very close to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you're too far away,  Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout his speech, Anne never takes  her eyes off him. As he fumbles now,  he turns. Their eyes meet. His overwhelming  desire for Anne overcomes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dismisses as futile his effort to  be practical, sweeps her into his arms  and kisses her passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CITY ROOM OF MORNING POST - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Stew at his desk, which is  directly in front of the battery of  Morkrums whose clatter comes into the  sound track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew finishes up a phone call. He sits  at his desk, staring pensively at his  typewriter. He is smoking a pipe and  is in his shirt-sleeves. His hair is  rumpled, and strewn over the desk is  a bunch of crumpled up pieces of paper,  indicating that he has made numerous  unsuccessful starts at writing something.  A fresh blank sheet of paper is now  in the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearby, at another desk, asleep in a  swivel chair, with his feet elevated  to the desk, the low snoring of another  reporter blends with the sounds of the  Morkrums and other noises of the City  Room. At the reporter's elbow is a telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desk of Conroy, the City Editor. A small  upright plate on his desk indicates  his position. This is near the copy  desk. Characteristic activities are  background for any action that may take  place. Reporters come up to throw their  stories on Conroy's desk; the phone  rings, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy comes in with a large number of  newspapers under his arm which he throws  on Conroy's desk. There are several  copies of each of the rival newspapers  in town. Conroy spreads them out and  begins to examine them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is evident that he is nervous and  jumpy about something. Finally he starts  to pound the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Sheet of paper in typewriter  on which is being typed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she talks on the phone to one of  her girlfriends

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I got a new dress. A new hat too.  (listens) Well, I'll try to get Stew  to come with me. (she glances in his  direction) Yeah - he's all right. You  know, he thinks he's stuck on some society  gal. (listens) Naw, it won't last. It  better not last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastily glancing over the headlines  of the papers. The phone rings. Without  looking at it, Conroy answers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh, I'll be surprised, eh? Listen  if there's any news in that sheet that  I haven't thrown in the wastepaper basket,  I'll eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking down at the papers and  suddenly his eyes focus on something  which causes the cigar to drop from  his mouth and an expression of mingled  amazement and rage comes into his face.  We do not see at this point what it  is he has read, but we know it must  be something sensational. Abruptly he  hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, as he studies his typewriter.  Over his CLOSEUP comes the excited outraged  voice of Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of infinite weariness and disgust  comes over Stew's face and he grits  his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His general expression registers "Good  god, there he goes again." With one  finger he pounds out four letters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Sheet in typewriter: Next to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yanks the sheet out of the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy. He looks over and bellows furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You double-crossing hound! Come over  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gets up from his machine, crumples  the sheet of paper into a wad and flings  it at the sleeping reporter. The wad  strikes him in the face; he wakes abruptly  and automatically reaches for the phone.  He picks up the receiver and in a voice  fogged with sleep calls a number. Stew  exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Conroy's desk. Conroy's expression  is one of bitter reproach as he leans  back in his swivel chair as Stew approaches  and stands by the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen boss, if you're going to  kick about that expense accountВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you call yourself a reporter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of other reporters, the older man at  the copy desk, and perhaps a sob sister  or two nearby, who look up with expectant  interest, expecting to hear Stew get  a bawling out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At her desk. She looks up worried and  apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know news if you fell into  a mess of it, nose first. So you're  the bright lad that's never been scooped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on my own beat, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (howling so that he can be heard all  over the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Well, where were you when that happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps the copy of the Tribune furiously  and shoves it into Stew's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not knowing what it is all about, Stew,  with an injured expression, takes the  paper and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other reporters, copy readers, sob  sisters, etc., seeing the unusual commotion  and Stew's bewildered reaction, get  out of their chairs and cross over to  the City Desk, where they take up other  copies of the same paper to look at.  There are amazed and excited exclamations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, still staring dumbly at the paper.  A few others are crowding around, glancing  over his shoulder, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of people being scooped on  their own funerals, but this! Holy mackerel!  Why, it's news when Anne Schuyler gets  her fingernails manicured, but this!  She gets married to one of our own reporters  and the Tribune beat us to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! What do you guys want? Go on,  get back to your desks. Go back to your  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't tell me you were drunk at  the time and don't remember! Or is this  one of Bingy's snow-storms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no - it's true, all right, only  we didn't want to get it in print yet,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I've acquired one of  those new mother-in-laws, and we were  afraid she wouldn't understand the whole  idea. So we were going to wait till  she went to Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I care about your mother-in-law!  You're still working for this paper,  aren't you! Or are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's your business to get news!  And here you had a story right in your  own lap and you let the Tribune scoop  us on it. Making a first class Grade  A monkey out of me. If it ever happens  again - just don't bother about coming  back. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dismisses Stew with a wave of his  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew turns away from Conroy's desk,  and a group of his confreres come up,  surrounding him in a series of ad-lib  congratulations. (Some slightly profane,  pounding him on the back, whooping,  and in general manifesting great surprise  and glee.) This group is increased by  copy readers, office boys and everybody  jabbering and shouting at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew manages to break thru them and  exits from scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GallagherВ—to intercut with above scene.  She gets up and goes over, CAMERA PANNING  WITH HER and picks up another copy of  the paper and reads the headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face stricken and sick as she reads  about Stew's marriage. Abruptly she  turns away, out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Gallagher's empty desk. Stew comes  in trying to stave off the mob. He turns  on the congratulators, pushing them  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you mugs? Can't  a guy get married without all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forcibly breaks away from them and  walks back toward the door, the last  of the wisecracks and goodnatured jeers  being flung after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher is seated alone at a table,  looking very forlorn. Her life is suddenly  empty. A drink is in front of her, untouched.  She is fighting hard to keep her emotions  under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew enters the speakeasy and mingles  with patrons, who offer congratulations.  He comes to a stop by the table. She  looks up, forcing a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well! Gallagher, old pal!  There you are. What did you run away  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew draws out the other chair at the  table and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks across at her, grinning boyishly,  utterly unaware that what he has done  has hurt her deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you ran away. Aren't you going  to congratulate a guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I wish you all the luck in the  world, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand tenderly on his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you'll be very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew expands under the comradeship of  Gallagher. He wants to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, we'll be happy. What's the  matter with your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, wasn't I a lucky guy to fall into  a girl like that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he notices the newspaper, which Gallagher  has been reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that! I don't know how I rate  that, Gallagher. Gosh, there's a swell  girl. I want you to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who me? She wouldn't want to meet me.  I'm just an old load of hay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what - we'll have one of those  parties down at your house - one of  those spaghetti parties, you know. Gee,  we haven't had one of those in a long  time, have we Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since you broke into society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the time we had a spaghetti  party, and while I was serving the spaghetti  I dropped it on the floor, and while  those mugs weren't looking, I picked  it up and served it to them anyway!  Remember that? Yes, Anne would love  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think your wife would walk up  three flights of stairs just to eat  out of paper plates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who - Anne? Sure, Anne would love that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get this, Gallagher - Smith. That's  the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if she doesn't want to come, I'll  come down alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, you won't, Mr. Smith. You're  a married man now. Mother always warned  me never to run around with married  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what kind of a pal are you? You're  not going to leave me flat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher tries to be elaborately casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll call you up some time. And  if your social duties permit - why -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut that out. Just because I'm married  - there's no reason for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher looks up and off, seeing something  that startles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy, the City Editor, entering the  speakeasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew buries his head in the newspaper,  in pretense of looking for something.  Conroy appears at the table and stops.  He indicates Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the Benedict[8] looking for in  the newspaper - his lost freedom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew slowly sticks his head up over  the top of the table, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't old Fagin[9] himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher and myself just came over  here to do a little work on a story  -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher tries to be very bright and  smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it swell about Stew's marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, self-conscious, realizes  this tough old buzzard is on to her.  She looks back at him for a moment -  then drops her head. Stew is oblivious  to this by-play. Conroy turns to Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quitting? I'm not thinking about quitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe comes in with a drink for Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you don't have to work for  a living any moreВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a sip of his drink and looks  over meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get this, Conroy. My name is Smith.  Always was Smith - and always gonna  be Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows that he is genuinely interested  in Stew and his problems, but can't  help being a little sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Schuyler's in the Blue Book - you're  not even in the phone book. Think that  one over, sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to CLOSEUP of GALLAGHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS BACK to CLOSEUP of CONROY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blah! It's like a giraffe marrying a  monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen - you'll never be anything but  just the reporter that married the Schuyler's  millions. Stew Smith is dead and buried.  From now on, you'll be just Anne Schuyler's  husband. A rich

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wife's magnolia. If you can smoke that  without getting sick, you're welcome  to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to CLOSEUP of STEW:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Now, Gallagher, let me  do the talking. Get this, Conroy - Anne  Schuyler has got a lot of dough, all  right - and I married her, all right  - but her dough and me? No connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher is looking fixedly at Stew  - very much worried about Conroy's dismal  prophecies. Conroy shakes his head in  sorrowful gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he had not heard Stew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a boid in a gilded cage -[10]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me. A bird in a gilded cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you've been reading a lot of cheap  tabloids. Anne and myself are going  to move downtown in a nice little flat,  we're gonna forget all about this social  stuff, and we're gonna be known as Mr.  and Mrs. Stew Smith. How do you like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And live on your salary, I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, live on my salary - that is, until  I finish writing my play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one about the Siberian bloodhound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siberian bloodhound? No. That's been  all rewritten. It's laid in Araby now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy, having finished his drink, pushes  back his chair and rises. He puts an  affectionate hand on Stew's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry to see a good reporter  go blooeyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me know when you're quitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'For he's only a bird in a gilded cage,  a beautiful sight to seeВ—'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs loud and raucously and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher realizes that Conroy has hit  home with the truth and is sorry for  Stew. She puts her hand over his sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay attention to him, Stew. He  doesn't know what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay attention? I'm not paying any attention  to him. You think that guy could get  me upset? Hah! Not that mug. He's a  tough mug - hard, cynical. He doesn't  know the fine things in life - that  guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird in a gilded cage, huh? It's getting  so a guy can't step out without being  called a magnolia. Stew Smith, a magnolia!  Not me. Say, I'm not going to hang around  and be a speakeasy rat all my life!  I'll tell you that. Not me, not me.  I'm going to step out and mean something  in this world. You watch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he swirls his drink, clearly bothered,  lost in his own thoughts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, am I a lucky guy to be near Anne  Schuyler? I've been hit with a carload  of horseshoes, and believe me I know  it. Lucky, I'll say I'm lucky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I'm lucky, Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird in a gilded cage, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is her family going to feel about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her family? Oh, they'll be all right.  I'll bring them around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilded cage?! Besides, I'm not marrying  her family. Stew Smith in a gilded cage!  Stew Smith? Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That mug. What does he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another jury scene. This time it is  Anne who's on the carpet. Grayson, in  correct afternoon attire, his hands  behind his back and his head sunk, is  pacing back and forth in a very depressed  and gloomy fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is seated, her demeanor betokening  sullen defiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is pacing, nervously smoking  a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you need me here for  - it isn't my funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler stands by a table, staring  at a spreadout newspaper which is laid  out on the table. She flings the newspaper  aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay right here, Michael. Some day  you'll be head of this family, but thank  heaven I shan't be here when it happens.  And I hope you never have a daughter  who gives you gastritis as Anne has  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the bell rope for the butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mother, calm yourself. There's no  use in getting so excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler bows and exits. She passes  a nervous hand over her eyes. Anne comes  up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, if you keep this up, you'll  have a nervous breakdown before you  go to Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing your father passed  away before he saw insanity ravage the  family. I can't imagine what made you  do such a thing. A reporter! Of all  things, a reporter! A barbarian who  lets his socks come down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I promise you that he won't  be a reporter much longer. Once I get  him away from that atmosphere and get  him away from a man named GallagherВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Anne starts to get up again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler enters with a tray on which  is a glass of bicarbonate of soda and  brings it to Mrs. Schuyler. Walking  immediately behind the butler is Stew,  airily debonair. The butler glances  somewhat uneasily at Mrs. Schuyler as  he presents the tray. She glares blackly  at Stew without a word of greeting,  and taking the foaming glass from the  tray, starts to lift it to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more, Anne starts to rise out of  her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler pauses - glowering at  Stew. Stew nods perfunctorily to each  member of the jury, the total innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson does not acknowledge the greeting.  Mrs. Schuyler, having drained the glass,  dismisses the butler with a wave of  the hand, and directs her attention  again to the matter at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's to be done? He's here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all silent - reluctant to speak  in front of Stew. Stew looks at them  all - a little puzzled - then he walks  over toward Mrs. Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody seems to want to do anythingВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not ask me? Perhaps I can offer  a suggestion. Do what about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? Your marriage to Anne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my marriage to Anne. Now Mrs. Schuyler,  we don't want you to go to any trouble  about that. We just want the usual blessings,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler's eyes flash. She draws  herself up with haughty dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, I want you to know that I  object violently to this whole affair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This finally brings Anne out of her  seat. She rises and crosses to Stew,  making a show of embracing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mother, your attitude is perfectly  ridiculous. It's done now. Stewart and  I are married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she's right, Mrs. Schuyler.  I'm really very sorry, Mrs. Schuyler,  that you feel this way. I was in hopes  that you would like me. I'm not the  burglar that you think I am. After all,  we're married. I think the thing to  do is to kiss and make up - Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man's impossible! I can't talk  to him. Grayson, let's go where we can  talk - hic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she emits a burp, then fixes a glacial  look at Anne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what you've done to me!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without another word, she turns and  flounces angrily out of the room. Grayson  follows her. At the doorway he pauses,  starts to say something. They all look  at him expectantly - but no words come  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson gives a harrumph and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, Michael and Stew. Michael grins  at Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael starts moving toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid your mother won that round  - that is, she got in the last blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel the way they do. You're  really not as bad as everybody thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're beginning to appreciate me, eh?  Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry too much about Mother -  she's enjoying this. Come on upstairs,  I'll give you a little -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates a snifter, grins and exits.  Anne crosses to Stew and puts her arm  around his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A littleВ—? Sure, I'll be right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right. I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees two figures pass above in a  proscenium alcove, first Mrs. Schuyler,  then Grayson. He makes an elaborate  bow to each, and is impressed by Grayson's  return bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne takes a step backwards and sits  down with him on one of the divans.  CAMERA TILTING DOWN WITH THEM. He puts  an arm about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne starts fussing abstractedly at  Stew's tie. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you for three hours.  You're neglecting me alreadyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During her speech she has been picking  away at a stain on his tie. Stew looks  down and notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Something I et, no  doubt. Egg marks the spotВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to get some new ties, Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need any new ties. I've got  another tie - I've got another one besides  this one. And it's a pip, too. There's  only one thing wrong with it. You know  what that is? It has a little weakness  for gravy, and once in a while it leans  a little toward ketchup. Of course that's  only in its weaker moments. When you  move down to my place, I'll show it  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is somewhat taken aback at the  suggestion that she's to move into his  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Oh, it's great. Of course it doesn't  compare with this coliseum of yours  here, but 'twill serve m'lady, 'twill  serve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The architecture has a little feeling  of Missouri Gothic - and the furniture  sort of leans toward Oklahoma Renaissance  - with a tiny touch of Grand Rapids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
