dialogues.text: Don't you think it's silly of us to  think of living there when we have this  whole big houseВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When 'we' . . .? You mean, you'd like  to have me live here in your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne cuddles closer into his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. We can have the whole left wing  and be all by ourselves all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have the whole left wing? Wouldn't  that be nice! Would that be room enough  for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh darling, of course it would. If it  isn't - there are six rooms and two  baths - but if that isn't enough, Mother  will give us the blue room too, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mother will give us the blue room.  You haven't a red room, have you? Well,  bless her heart. Wouldn't that be nice!  My, oh my - six rooms and two baths  and a blue room. I guess she would let  us have the right wing if we needed  it, wouldn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we don't need it, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, we won't need that. Plenty of  room, plenty of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and paces the floor. He looks  at Anne and sees that she is taking  him seriously. He drops down beside  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Anne, you're not serious about  this, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuddles closer, tweaking his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the cutest nose I'veВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind my nose. What kind of a chump  do you think I am? You think I'm going  to live here in your house - on your  dough? What do you think my friends  would all say? Don't be silly. I'd get  the razzing of my life for that. 'A  bird in a gilded cage' - that's what  I'd be. Not me. Oh no, not me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think my friends would say  if they found me in a little cheap flat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Stew baby, let's not talk about  things like that nowВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I'll do anything you  ask me, Anne, but I will not liveВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I love that nose. It's such a sweet  nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, whether the nose is sweet  or not, I'm not going to live in your  house. You may as well get that straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do want me to be happy, don't you?  Then I'm not going to live in your house  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bed, asleep, all curled up, his head  on his arm. CAMERA TRUCKS BACK showing  the magnificent bedroom, with carved  wooden panellings, a raised, canopied  bed. The clothes that Stew has taken  off the night before are draped haphazardly  about the room. When the Camera gets  to a point that takes in a LONG SHOT  of the room, the door to the hall opens  and a correctly attired valet appears.  He closes the door noiselessly, goes  over to the windows, and draws the brocaded  drapes aside. Then he crosses to a covered  object and with a small flourish removes  the cover - revealing a birdcage. He  approaches the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dawson the valet stops beside the  bed. The valet leans over and speaks  distinctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no movement from the form on  the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no response. The valet taps the  bedclothes-shrouded shoulder gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleepily, Stew turns, his eyes heavy  with sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like your bath, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my bath all right. How do you  like your bath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your valet, sir. Dawson is the name,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew still stares at him. Then he nods  to himself - thinks he gets the idea.  Stew kicks back the covers and sits  on the edge of the bed in his pajamas.  Still sitting on the edge of the bed,  he starts to slip his feet into a pair  of slippers. The valet bends on one  knee to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you! I'll  do that for you some time. That's very  sweet. Say listen, what did you say  your name was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson, huh? Was I very drunk last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew rises and starts to reach for a  dressing gown, but again the valet beats  him to it - holding it for him and helping  him slip into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I must have been pretty much plastered  if I hired a valet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you didn't engage me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, surprised, turns on him quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did engage you then, if I didn't  engage you? What are you doing with  my pantsВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet picks up his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you take anything out of those pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing fooling around in  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Schuyler - I mean, Mrs. Smith -  she engaged me this morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew pulls out a cigarette. The valet,  without missing a beat, leans over and  offers a light. A wary Stew accepts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. So Mrs. Smith engaged me a valley,  huh? That's very nice of Mrs. Smith  - to engage me a valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew walks over and gets a cigarette  out of a box on a small table, waving  his hand in a gesture of dismissal.  The valet is right behind him, holding  up his bathrobe for Stew to step into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you are nice. You're all right.  You'd make a good wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for me! Though I like you well  enough. You're a nice fellow. You're  all right. But I'm sorry I don't need  any valleys today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet pays no attention to him,  but walks around the room, picking up  the clothes that Stew has flung about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but indeed you do, sir, if you don't  mind my saying so. A gentleman's gentleman,  as it were. Someone to draw your bath,  lay out your clothes, help to dress  you - it's really most essential, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, with his cigarette between his  lips, stands watching the valet as he  retrieves the various articles of cast-off  clothing. The valet's manner is somewhat  patronizing. He walks over to a chifferobe  and starts opening the drawers, preparatory  to laying out fresh things for Stew.  Suddenly, Stew stalks over to him, takes  him by the shoulder, and yanks him around  to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet is astonished and somewhat  alarmed at the belligerent expression  on Stew's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me that I need  someone to help me put on my pants and  button them up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm sorry. I appreciate your efforts.  But I don't need anybody to help me  button my pants - I've been buttoning  my pants for thirty years all right,  and I can button 'em with one hand as  a matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is rapidly losing his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a nice face, Dawson, you  wouldn't want anything to happen to  your face, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet puts a bewildered hand to  his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew releases him with a definite motion  toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet gazes at Stew as if he thinks  the man is insane. He is considerably  alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I understand, sir. You mean  you want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. You caught on. You see,  you're nice and you're smart too. You  caught on right away. Outside! Go on!  Outside! And don't come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet starts edging toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew's eyes bulge as he notices the  birdcage for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a canary! Who brought that in  here? Canary, huh? Go on, get that out  of here. Get that out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird! A bird in a gilded cage! Get  that thing out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet hurries off, carrying the  birdcage. As he nears the door, there  is a light tap on the door connecting  Stew's room and Anne's. The door opens  and Anne comes in, wearing a ravishing  and revealing negligee. She carries  a small jeweler's box in her hand. She  crosses the room toward Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over and sees Dawson at the  hall door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dawson, see that all Mr. Smith's  clothes go to the cleaners this morning,  please, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet bows. Stew looks at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door discreetly and goes  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits down on the rumpled bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a present. Shut your eyes.  Keep 'em closed. I know you're going  to love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little - couldn't be an automobile,  could it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds them up - expensive garters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got my initials on them too. They're  cute. They're nice little things - what  do you do with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wear them of course, silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. No, no. Not me. I haven't worn  these things for Years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides I'd look foolish. I couldn't  look Gallagher in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, I don't care whether you can  look Gallagher in the face or not, but  you're gonna be a good boy and wear  garters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I love you. I'll eat spinach  for you. I'll go to the dentist twice  a year for you. I'll wash behind my  ears for you. But I will never wear  garters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His arms go about Anne. Under the force  of his embrace Anne sinks back on the  pillows. Stew leans forward looking  down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133. CLOSE TWO SHOT - STEW AND ANNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes you will my dear - oh, yes you  will my dear - you'll wear garters and  you'll like it too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no I won't my dear - oh, no I won't  my dear - I'll wash behind my ears,  but no I won't my dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends to kiss her again, but she  gently resists, and continues the sing-song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes you will my dear - oh, yes you  will my dear - you'll eat spinach but  you'll wear garters too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you can't carry a tune - you can't  carry a tune - all you are good for  is to sit and spoon, spoon. Oh no, I  won't wear gartersВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes you will wear gartersВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They melt into each other's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CITY ROOM OF NEWSPAPER OFFICE -  DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS DOWN THE MAIN AISLE until  it centers on Stew at his desk, sitting  low in his chair, his feet cocked up  on the corner of his desk, reading a  newspaper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS UP CLOSER centering on  his feet on the desk. One trouser leg  is pulled slightly up and reveals a  garter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, reading the newspaper. It is opened  up before his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Headlines - about a three-column  article:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE SCHUYLER AND CINDERELLA HUBBY TO  OCCUPY SCHUYLER MANSION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew reads this, he looks very glum  and depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reporter, the one Stew had socked  with a wad of paper in an earlier sequence,  shambles past and stops abruptly, staring  at Stew's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Of what he sees. Stew's feet.  The socks are strangely taut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporter glances up and sees that  Stew cannot see him, and then carefully  lifts Stew's trouser leg a few inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Stew's feet and legs. As the  reporter's hand lifts the trouser leg,  the fancy solid-gold garters are on  full display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporter stares at them goggle-eyed.  He can hardly contain himself at the  sight of the garters. He looks off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One or two other reporters hear him  and look over curiously. The reporter  looks very mysterious and important  and makes a motion for silence and caution.  They get up and cross on tip-toe to  join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men around Stew. They quietly gather  around his feet and the reporter who  made the discovery proudly displays  his find. One or two more step by and  all stare. Stew still has the paper  up in front of his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta set him back at least six bits.[11]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew. (Camera behind him and shooting  over his head.) He is suddenly attracted  by this unusual conversation and lowers  his paper, revealing the group of six  or seven men in a huddle round his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One just can't wear those and be decent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you can, if you belong to the Four  Hundred.[12]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what number he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew flares in anger. Several of them  are bending low to get a close peek.  With a violent gesture, Stew kicks his  foot forward and sends a couple of them  sprawling. Stew gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get out of there! What's the  matter with you mugs? Didn't you ever  see a guy with a pair of garters on  before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two reporters who have done most  of the talking scramble to their feet.  The second reporter speaks in mock perplexity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose he wears them for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it be possible to hold his socks  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, one's hose look horribly untidy  when they hang loose-like, don't you  think so, percifield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gets up as his phone rings. He  pays no attention to it. Hank, another  reporter, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my dear chap - they look ghastly  - they look ghastly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on! Screw! Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out when Hank calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew comes back and, frowning, picks  up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Oh hello dear. Wait just a minuteВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Beat it, will you? Screw! Screw!  This is my wife! In your respective  chapeaux and over your cauliflower ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad-lib teasing comments as they exit  scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is lying on her stomach on a rubbing  table, as used by a masseuse. We see  a considerable part of her back, on  which a middle-aged Swedish masseuse  is industriously working. Anne has the  telephone in her hand. Throughout her  scene, we hear very telling whacks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's nearly six o'clock darling,  and you know how long it takes you to  dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Ambassador is coming at eight,  and you've got to be ready by the time  he gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two footmen stand at either side of  a huge iron gate. Cars and limousines  are arriving, dropping off guests in  evening wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145. Gallagher is just entering. Smythe  holds door open for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Miss Wilson, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSS AND FONTANA are doing a beautiful  tango. Guests scattered around the room,  watching interestedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher is still waiting. Smythe enters,  leading Miss Wilson, a refined-looking  girl of 26 or so, her hand extended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes - of course. Miss Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Miss Wilson - Mrs. Schuyler's social  secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sent from the Post in place of  our social editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Miss Ramsey telephoned  me. Well, what would you like to have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, a list of the guests. That's the  usual thing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. I'll get it for youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, would you like to take  a look around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they start  for the Reception Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Smith? Oh, you mean Ann Schuyler's  husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably very tired. You see, he's  had to meet all these people personally  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You newspaper people have a lot of fun  with him, don't you? What is it you  call him - the Cinderella Man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss and Fontana are just finishing  their dance. Gallagher stands in doorway  with Miss Wilson, watching them. Excited  voices comment on the dance. Miss Wilson  beckons to Gallagher to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS with them as they weave  in and out of crowd. Miss Wilson points  out celebrated guests to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher steals a glance at the celebrated  gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, he looks like one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wilson laughs delightedly. At this  point they are interrupted by a butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Smith would like to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me? Make yourself at  home for just a moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wilson follows butler out of scene.  Gallagher is left alone. She wanders  about the huge ballroom, peering here  and there, searching for Stew. Finally  she comes to a large open French door  and steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 150. INT. TERRACE LEADING OFF SCHUYLER  BALLROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several groups of men and women are  seated at tables. Gallagher enters from  ballroom, glances quickly at all the  men. Disappointed at not finding Stew,  she crosses terrace and descends broad  stone steps and advances into garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, his head cupped in his hands,  is seated on a stone bench. Gallagher  wanders into scene. She sees Stew and  stops. Stew does not move. Gallagher,  with a happy smile on her lips, moves  closer to him. Stew suddenly becomes  conscious of someone near him and looks  suddenly up. He sees Gallagher; his  face breaks into a happy grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Smith, I've read some of your plays  and I'd like an autograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well! If it isn't my old friend!  Turn around, gal! Let's get a look at  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, daughter of the slums - how did  you get out of the ghetto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pinch-hitting for our society editor  tonight. I wanted to see some life in  the raw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you wanted to see some life in the  raw, huh? Well gal, I'm afraid we ain't  got no raw life up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll have to look someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no! Maybe we could interest you  in some well done butterflies, or perhaps  some slightly fried pansies, or better  still, some stuffed shirts. And guaranteed  every one of them will give you a good  stiff pain in the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, who's been tying your ties lately?  It looks rotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly realizes there's something  different about Gallagher. He takes  a step back so as to look her over carefully  - blinks his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee Gallagher, do you look good! What  are you doing to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do to that hair? And where  did you get that dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dyed one and washed the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you dyed one and washed the other.  Well! You certainly look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is walking in direction of Stew  and Gallagher. She stops suddenly when  she sees them. Her body stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Anne's angle. Gallagher is facing  in the direction of Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't turn around now - but there's  a very beautiful girl up there who seems  to be staring at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my wife. Hi Anne. Don't go away.  Stay right there, because I'm going  to bring a friend up I want you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing as before. She is looking off  with slightly narrowed eyes. Stew and  Gallagher come up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, prepare yourself for the treat  of your life. This is Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure - my pal on the paper. She's subbing  for the society editor tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne turns an acid smile on the uncomfortable  Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, of course. How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne winces slightly at this name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a short, awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Stewart, you failed to mention  that Miss Gallagher was a very beautiful  young girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher flashes a look at Stew - seeing  that he fails to get the dynamite behind  Anne's casually pleasant phrases. Anne  plunges ahead. Her tone is unmistakable  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. As a matter of fact, you failed  to mention that Gallagher was a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I? That's funny. Isn't it funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is beginning to realize that all  is not well as it could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, we never look at Gallagher  as a girlВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? What do you look upon her as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, down at the office, we always look  at Gallagher as - eh - just Gallagher,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS QUICKLY TO CLOSE SHOT of  GALLAGHER. She tries to back Stew up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all consider me just as one of  the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne takes Stew's arm, drawing him away  from Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wilson will give you the guest  list and any other details you may need,  Miss Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'll go and look for her  at once. Goodbye, Mrs. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158. MED. CLOSE SHOT - STEW AND ANNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was kind of a rotten thing to do,  Anne. After all, Gallagher is my friend.  The least you can do is be courteous  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was very charming, Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did? That's a lot of hooey! I'll  go and apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He promptly walks away from her in Gallagher's  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glares angrily at the departing  Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher has just reached the ballroom  when Stew catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Gallagher - really, I am  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right, Stew. Forget it.  As far as she's concerned, I'm just  part of the hired help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Strange, I've never seen Anne  act that way before. (pause) It's funny  I never thought to tell her you were  a girl, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler is just opening the door.  Bingy, looking more disreputable than  usual, steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it you wish to see, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see Stew Smith. Oh excuse  me - I mean Mr. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Mr. Smith is engaged. We  are having a reception here this eveningВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a party! Great, great! Jolly times  and merry pranks. That's me. I'm a guy  who loves parties. You knowВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is distracted by two elegantly-dressed  ladies strolling by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—a beautiful pair of shoulders! But  listen now, as a favor, will you please  make it snappy, Laughing Waters,[14]  and tell Stew Smith I gotta see him  because if you don't my whole family's  going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell Mr. Smith at once, sir. Have  a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got a seat, but I have no place  to put it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler turns to leave, then turns  back, his face expressing distinct disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, sir, but I've heard that  one before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew and Gallagher standing together.  The butler is seen leaving the scene,  having just informed Stew of Bingy's  presence at the reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I just want to make sure  and see he doesn't take away any of  the vases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well! My little pal, Gallagher,  a girl, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unexpectedly, he bends to kiss her  hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just to give you an idea that  I know how to treat a gal. Get fresh  with me and I'll sock you in that little  nose of yours. Excuse me. I'll be right  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Gallagher is left staring  at her hand wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy gets up from his throne chair,  and crosses into the doorway of the  library opposite him. He stops by a  carved low-boy, and curiously examines  a large antique vase. Stew comes in  and stops with a smile as he sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy, his hand on the vase, looks up.  Stew walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Bingy, a little clumsy  to get in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy sets down the vase and surveys  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was just looking at it. Pretty,  ain't it? I was just looking for the  price tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy looks him up and down in silent,  insolent scrutiny. Stew begins to burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. I just blew over - I wanted  to see how the old newshound looked  made up for a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to have me turn around  for you, Bingy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew makes a complete turn and faces  Bingy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad - not good - but not bad. You  ought to be able to fool about almost  anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? Well, have you seen enough  - or would you like a photograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph? What's the matter? Hasn't  mama had you done in oils yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get this mug. You've got the kind  of chin I just love to touch. And if  you don't get out of here, I'm going  to hang one right on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy! Take it easy, Dempsey.[16]  Just relax, my boy, relax and open your  pores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew glares at him. Bingy goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bring a message from Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The boss sent me over to offer  you a job. He wants you to write a daily  column on the Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. You can write your own  ticket. A hundred and fifty bucks a  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no catch. This is on the up  and up. Of course all you have to do  is just sign the article - by Anne Schuyler's  Husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in the doorway. The butler starts  to pass by. Stew's eyes are blazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how does the old Cinderella man  feel about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a quick motion, Stew clips Bingy  on the jaw. Bingy, caught unawares,  reels backward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy describes a backward arc, just  as Smythe, the butler, seeing he can  be of service, steps forward and catches  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I think of it, Bingy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy sags in the butler's arms. The  butler looks at Stew inquiringly. Stew  nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, the - er - gentleman is leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy is carried out. Stew stands glaring  after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and her mother at the breakfast  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mother. Didn't I tell  you that he'd be marvelous. Everybody  thought he was so charming last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so worried for fear he'd knock  over a vase or something. I must have  acted like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (notices the morning paper in Anne's  hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it say about the reception  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual thing. Blah, blah, blah  attended the blah, blah reception and  wore the same blah, blah things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it. Anne. You're behaving like  the person you're married to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have anything to complain  about, Mother. He was all right last  night, wasn't he? I told you not to  worry about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a miracle. The man was ill or  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly notices front page of paper  Anne is reading. Her face freezes in  horror. She screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne turns paper and reads the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA MAN GROWS HAIR ON CHEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I wear the pants," says Anne Schuyler's  husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schuyler gets up. Paces wildly  about room. In a frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it! I knew it! I felt it in my  bones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is interrupted by the entrance of  Grayson, who dashes into the room, his  eyes ablaze. In his hand he has a copy  of the morning paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the papers? "Cinderella  Man Grows Hair On Chest!" This is the  most terrible kind of publicity that  could possiblyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I know it, Grayson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Smythe the butler enters with tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith - send for Mr. Smythe! Er - Smythe,  send for Mr. Smith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I wear the pants," says Anne Schuyler's  husband!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew, now dressed in a business suit,  comes from the direction of the stairs  and stops just before he gets to the  door of the drawing room. From within  there is an ominous silence. Stew looks  longingly in the direction of the front  door - then back at the drawing room,  squares his shoulders and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew stops just inside the doorway.  He had been prepared for this, but it  strikes terror into his soul, just the  same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his angle in the doorway. The jury  - Dexter Grayson, hands behind his back  - is standing, gazing at Stew with a  fishy eye. Mrs. Schuyler stares haughtily.  Anne is crying softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew - looking around at the gallery  of faces. Then he forces a jaunty smile  to his face as he starts to enter, whistling  as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he gets a cold, frigid, silent reception)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it isn't a good morning,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, did you ever get the feeling that  there was someone else in the room with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a worm - and I'm gonna step on  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To engage in a brawl! A cheap, common  brawl, in my own home! "I wear the pants!"  The pants ! Not even the trousers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to stop the evening papers,  but it's useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You quit trying to stop anybodyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at best you might deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why deny it? The more you deny, the  more they print. Let them alone! The  thing to do is to sit still and keep  our traps shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly! I'll take care of this guy  Bingy myself, personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what are you crying about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this true, Stewart? Did you really  say it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I said it. Sure, I said it. I didn't  say it for publication, however.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you struck him right here in our  houseВ—?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sorry, I struck him right here  in your house. And I'll strike anybody  in anybody's house that calls me a Cinderella  Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what else do you expect them to  call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the fourteenth crack you've made  to me. I'm keeping count. When you get  to twenty, I'm gonna sock you right  on the nose. As a matter of fact, I  ought to sock you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Schuyler, are you going to sit  there and watch this man insult us?  Haven't you any decency left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't Dexter show some decency?  And you might show some too, Mother.  What do you expect a man to do when  he's called such names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you hit that reporter, Stewart.  He deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right! It's your funeral,  Anne Schuyler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flounces out. Grayson remains behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson turns to go, then braves the  last word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves in a huff. Stew puts his arms  around the crying Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six or eight people of distinction scattered  around the room. All dressed in full  evening clothes. Among them is Grayson,  Anne, her mother, and one man in aviator's  uniform. The men have their coats and  hats in their hands, the women have  their evening wraps on. Apparently they  are ready to leave for someplace and  are being detained. An indistinct murmur  of ad-lib conversation is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Smythe, the butler, as he approaches  Mrs. Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, madam. They phoned through  from the Mayor's committee to remind  you it's past the hour for the reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been ready for the last half  hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including Captain White, a young, handsome  aviator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I don't have to make any speeches  tonight, Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you can't disappoint all the women.  After all it isn't every day they get  to see a famous round-the-world flier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know, but they scare me to death.  This is the fourth dinner you've taken  me to this week. I'm running out of  material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there are always too many other  people around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, it's getting late. What are we  waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, I'll run up and  see what the slowpoke's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts out, climbing stairs to Stew's  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew stands in front of a mirror, fumbling  with his dress tie. He pauses, his hands  still on his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart! We're all waiting for you.  Where's your valet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop trying to be funny, and get ready,  will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he struggles with his collar, it  springs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about - I'm not going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going downstairs and tell  those people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go downstairs, and tell them - anything.  Tell them I'm not going. Tell them I'm  not home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart, would you mind telling me why  you're not going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll tell you - for the same reason  I've never wanted to go out with those  social parasites, those sweet-smelling  fashion plates. I don't like them. They  bore me. They give me the jitters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know you're talking about my  friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm talking about your friends,  and they still give me the jitters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, are you going - or aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew makes a move to embrace her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out for my lipstick, Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what. Let's you and me  sneak out all by ourselvesВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the fun we can have - we'll  sneak down the back stairs and get in  the valet's Ford. How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop being silly, Stewart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what let's do - I'll take  you and introduce you to all my gang.  Would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want to meet your gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean the newspaper fellows that  you don't like. Another gang I know  - you'd love them. They're writers and  musicians and artists - a great crowd  of people - people who do great things.  People who are worthwhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning, my friends aren't worthwhile,  I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're all right, Anne. But IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what you mean. Heaven  knows you've made that clear to me often  enough. Well, I'm sick and tired of  it. I've given you party after party  - I've taken you to some of the best  houses in this town - and introduced  you to people of importance - and are  you grateful? No! You insult them and  act like a bore. I'm sick and tired  of having to make excuses for you and  the things that you've done. Perhaps  it's just as well you're not coming  tonight. Maybe I can enjoy myself for  once without having to worry about you,  and what you're going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With which violent declaration, she  flounces out of the room, leaving Stew  staring after her, angry and hurt. Impulsively,  he follows her to the door - a retort  on his lips. When he gets there, however,  she has vanished. He returns to the  room, wanders about thoughtfully, extracts  cigarette from box, fumbles it - walks  to window - stares out - turns back  to room - heaves a lonely sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices his reflection in the mirror,  and gestures toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that, my friends, is what is known  as the society belle telling ex-star-newspaper-reporter  to go to - how-have-you-been, Mr. Smith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew sits in a typewriter chair.  He rolls up the sheet in the machine  so that he can read what is already  written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strumming of guitars are dimly heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies it for a moment, frowning  in dissatisfaction. He's stuck. He leans  back in the chair and looks up for inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: A BIG CLOCK, TICKING AWAY THE  TIME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Stew Smith pacing the grand foyer.  Seen from overhead, he is dwarfed by  the surroundings. He tries hopscotching  on the pattern of the floor. That wears  thin quickly. Supremely bored, Stew  gives a shout and is rewarded with a  cavernous echo. Smythe the butler then  appears, nervously crouched behind some  grillwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, come here. I want to talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Smythe, talk to me. Smythe,  I'm going nuts. I'm going nuts in this  house! This big . . . come on, I'm not  going to hurt you. Come on, what's the  matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gives another shout and is rewarded  with another loud echo. This coaxes  Smythe out from behind the grillwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe gives it a timid try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Give it more volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe gives a more satisfactory yell.  Stew nods approval. Smythe begins yelling  and shouting in earnest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's enough. I just wanted you  to get the idea. Now you know. This  house is haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Have you looked in the closets  all over . . .?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe has heard enough. He turns to  leave, but Stew grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, what do you do with yourself  - I mean, when you're not carrying those  double-strength - what do you do with  yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe! I mean - when you're alone and  want to amuse yourself, then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm, you just putter. Do you have to  have a putter to putter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, sir. I putter with me hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, isn't that nice? You just go right  ahead and putter with your hands. That's  all right. How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He demonstrates, touching objects on  a table and blowing dust off a lampshade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Well, well, well! That's all right,  if you like it. Can anybody do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, sir. Some people are natural  putterers. Others can never master it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my. You mean, some people are born  and never will become putterers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, wouldn't that be tragic? To know  that you could never be a putterer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about me? Do you think if I concentrated  and put my whole soul into it, that  some day I might be a putterer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sir? Uh-uh. You could never be a  putterer. Not a good putterer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I couldn't be a good putterer,  I wouldn't want to putter. But why?  What makes you think I couldn't be a  good putterer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sir, to be a putterer, one's mind  must be at ease. A person with a problem  could never be a putterer. For instance,  sir, a fish can putter in water but  not on land because he'd be out of place.  An eagle can putter around a rugged  mountaintop but not in a cage, because  he'd be restless and unhappy. Now sir,  if you will pardon me, with all due  respect, sir, as a Smythe to a Smith,  you are an eagle in a cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird in a gilded cage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I wanted to know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew rushes off upstairs. Smythe gives  the echo one last try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew makes a telephone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Gallagher old pal. How are you,  old pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple room, probably in a boarding  house or cheap hotel. Gallagher is on  the phone. A typewriter stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello Stew. I'm pretty good, can't  complain. How's our gentleman of leisure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the coast of Norway and I can't  get out - will you come and get me out  of the coast of Norway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, your play. Hmmm, Act One, Scene  One: Coast of Norway - and then a lot  of blank. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on, don't be silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, if you feel like you need  a chaper-one, call up Hank. Yeah. You'll  find him at Joe's, no doubt. Yeah. Hank  would be my idea of a perfect bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you would. I knew I could depend  on you, old pal. Snap it up, will you,  Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, joyful at the prospect  of seeing Stew. She hums softly to herself  as she picks up the receiver again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew comes out of the library. Smythe  is going down the hall. Stew intercepts  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, I'll get this. I'm expecting  some friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At entrance door. Stew enters and opens  it. Gallagher and Hank enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Gallagher! Glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come right in - I'll get you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sort of invited him along to bend  an elbow. You don't mind, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Bring him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe appears in the open doorway. Stew  sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Joe. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello kid, how are you? Glad to see  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew starts to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute - Johnson's outside. You  don't mind if he comes in and dips a  beak[17] do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, bring him in. The more the merrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson appears in the open doorway.  Stew sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Stew, old pal. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to see you. Come in, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew starts to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I got two of the boys  I brought along - they were cruising  around with nothing to do. You don't  mind if I bring them in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought two of the boys? That's  all right. Bring them in. What's the  difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two enter, followed in a single  file by 12-14 men and women, all of  whom greet Stew as they enter, ad-libbing  hello's and hand-shakes. Stew stares  at them dumbfoundedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They swarm into the hallway and overflow  into the rooms on either side. The butler  stands aghast at this invasion. Stew  starts to close the door when three  or four more troop in, shouting cheery  greetings. Stew regards them in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he watches them file past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the gang had to get out  the morning edition - but they'll be  down later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Hank, are you sure they're coming?  It will be lonesome without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe, take this crowd in there and  give them a drink. And find out what  the boys in the back room want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe gulps nervously, as he is dragged  off by the revellers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang have taken seriously Stew's  suggestion that they make themselves  at home. They have draped themselves  about the place - a couple are strumming  on the piano and others are inspecting  the room in awe-struck attitudes. Smythe  is being propelled around the room by  the revellers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't done, gentlemen! It isn't done,  I say! It isn't done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Gallagher, you certainly took  no chances, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Stew. I asked Hank, and Hank  did the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Hank brought them all. That's  all right. We'll give them a drink and  throw 'em out. How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Smythe passes by, being propelled  by revellers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe! Give them one drink and throw  'em out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy pokes his head in the door, wearing  a false beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a green elephant standing beside  that bwana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just little Bingy Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew rolls up his sleeves, preparatory  to launching a punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy dons a pair of glasses, and points  to them meaningfully. He enters, cautiously,  watching Stew warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Chief Bingy come to white man's  tepee to make friends. Big Chief very  sorry. To show how sorry - will bend  over and let white man kick Big Chief  where sun never shines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Gallagher. I wouldn't miss  this one for the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends over, and Stew winds up and  delivers a hard kick to his backside.  Bingy straightens stiffly, then removes  a bottle of alcohol from the target  area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Stew, that's all thrashed out.  By golly, I'm surely glad to see that  you're not really sore. You know our  racket - after all, news is news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. That's all right. That was  a great story, Bingy. A great story  - wish I'd printed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you the breaks, didn't I? That  hairy chest story!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've raised it up to the chin, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on in the other room and get yourself  a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingy emits a war-whoop and proceeds  into the drawing room, where Smythe  is still being held hostage by the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I should do with you?  I should sock you right in that funny  little nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws her out of the entrance hall,  and the CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they  head upstairs, the party around them  going in full force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew and Gallagher enter. Apparently  they have been talking about Stew's  play on the way upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've just been able to get off  that Norway coast - so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gestures toward the typewriter  from which a sheet of paper is protruding.  Gallagher crosses to it. She rolls up  the sheet so she can read what is typed  on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Act One - Scene One - A Street in Old  MadridВ—'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns as Stew walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not getting your play done,  but you're certainly covering a lot  of territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I covered some territory? It  feels like I've been on a Cook's Tour[18]  some place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart, have you ever been to Old Madrid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never even been to New Madrid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you expect to write about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - draw on my imagination, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Conrad draw on his imagination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is brought up with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about Conrad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know a thing about him, but  isn't he the one you're always yelling  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is noticeably impressed with this  point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher warms up to her subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he the one that always writes  about things - only the things he knows  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't he go to sea before he wrote  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you write about something  you know? Write about yourself and Anne.  The poor boy who marries a rich girl  - now there's a swell theme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, that's an idea, Gallagher. That's  an idea there. I wonder now . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. She'd make a beautiful heroine  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warming up - he puts arm around Gallagher's  shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's her mother - and what a  character that old dame would make with  her double-strength - and that lawyer  friend of theirs - he'd make a great  villain - and there's you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspiration striking, he dashes to  the typewriter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an idea, Gallagher. Let's get  this set. That's a great idea for a  play. Pal, get me a cigarette, will  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, thanks. Now, let's see. How  will I start? Hey pal, how would you  start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting through into the drawing room.  It is many hours later. The members  of the party, including Smythe, are  pretty well lit. On the floor of the  entrance hall a dice game is in progress.  In the drawing room four or five are  hanging over the piano singing "The  Grasshopper Jumped Over Another Grasshopper's  Back."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In general, a large time is being had.  As the scene opens a door-bell is ringing.  A key is heard in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 200. CLOSER SHOT - GROUP - IN ENTRANCE  HALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outer door starts to swing open.  One of the party guests, very wall-eyed  now, and carrying a whiskey bottle in  his hand, staggers toward the door.  It opens wider, and Anne and Mrs. Schuyler  and Dexter Grayson stand gasping in  the opening. The guest comes up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you can't come in here - this is  a private party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne pushes the door violently, which  sends the guest sprawling. He stays  where he lands, holding the bottle in  both arms across his chest. Anne and  her mother advance into a CLOSE SHOT  and look off with incredulous horror  and amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a drunk Bingy as he peers at them  from an alcove above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my old classmate from Harvard!  Whoopee! Harvard, '98!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most are too cock-eyed or too engrossed  in the ongoing crap game to notice them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who's the cause of it all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the men wanders in from the drawing  room in time to hear this conversation.  He assumes an attitude of exaggerated  courtesy and gallantry as he bows before  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and her mother are almost bursting  with fury. They spot Smythe, across  the room, thoroughly in his cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe! Smythe - who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe comes stumbling up, a grin plastered  on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends of mine. Very lit-lit-literary  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for crying out loud, I don't know.  And I don't care. Whoopee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew gets to his feet as an idea strikes  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Gallagher, if we could only get  a great scene - a tremendously emotional  scene - some-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: thing that would just wring the hearts  out of the public - to bring the curtain  down in the second act - that would  be okay. Couldn't dig one out of your  hat some place, could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope - afraid I'm all out of tricks  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, we've got it right up to where  the boy's wearing his white spats and  going to teas and the frau enters -  how's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the partially opened door into the  hall. It opens wider, and Anne looks  in. She stares in horrified amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, her shoes off, sprawled out  on the chaise longue, stretches luxuriously  and yawns. CAMERA PANS TO Stew at the  typewriter, hair mussed, coffee pot  and cups prominent, the dressing gown  over the back of his chair. Neither  of them has seen Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne. She gasps as she quietly steps  further into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, caught in the midst of a  grand stretch, sits up abruptly, startled.  She stares uncomfortably off at Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the typewriter. He glances up momentarily  and very absently, and goes right on  typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. What does this mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart looks up surprised at the tone  of her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, sensing scene, starts hastily  looking for her shoes. One of them has  been shoved under the chaise longue  and she has to get down on her hands  and knees to retrieve it. Anne comes  in and confronts them, her hands on  her hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that mob downstairs. I guess I got  so interested in the play I forgot all  about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we got a play, Anne? Oh, have we  got a play! Of course most of it is  Gallagher's. She did most of it. That  brain of hers just snaps like that all  the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates by snapping his fingers.  Gallagher quietly gathers up her things,  apprehensive of the storm about to break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in the way her brain  snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew stares at Anne as Gallagher, her  hat in her hand, her coat over her arm,  starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I better go, Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should, Miss Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher stops, transfixed by the new  tone in his voice. He comes over to  Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 209. CLOSE TWO SHOT - ANNE AND STEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea is simply this - that I want  those people to leave here immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. Aren't you being  a little unreasonable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unreasonable! Have you any idea what  the place looks like downstairs? Do  you expect me to stand here and see  this place turned into a cheap barroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait, don't get excited, Anne. There's  no reason for that. Perhaps the boys  have had a little too much to drink.  That's all right. I'm sorry. I'll go  right down and throw them out. That's  no reason for you to take this attitude.  After all, I certainly have a right  to invite a few of my friends to my  house, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. All right. I don't blame  you. I kinda forgot myself for a moment,  there. That's what I call getting me  told, isn't it, Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne remains silent. That's exactly  what she has done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I've been boarding out this  past year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his coat off back of chair  and slips into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll tell you thisВ—I don't  like your boarding house, ladyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gathers up loose manuscript, he  continues . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and if it's all the same to you, I'm  moving out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is something I should have done  a long time ago, only I didn't have  sense enough to do it. No, I had to  stick around here to try and make a  success of something that I knew darn  well was a failure from the very beginning.  But no more. No more! So that's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't walk out of here like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the scene, Stew is gathering  his things togetherВ—and probably packing  an overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I can't? Who's going to stop me?  I'd like to see somebody stop me. If  you think I'm going to stick around  this joint just to look at this mausoleum,  not on your life! You're going to make  no stuffed shirt out of me. Now what  do you think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here? Who is this woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan of Arc! What's it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'm insane, but I've got some good  news for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This magnolia is leaving your sweet  smelling vanilla joint. This bird in  a cage is gonna button his own pants  from now on. And that is what is known  as telling the mother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher's cry of joy is cut off by  an icy look from Mrs. Schuyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is stuffing things into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done nothing but watch me - watch  me! - ever since I've been here. Treated  me like a thug, watched me like a hawk,  mistrusted me. Every time I leave the  house, that JaneВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—goes out and counts the silverware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! I don't blame her. I know I'm  out of my own crowd. I should have had  better sense in the beginning. But I'll  stay in my own backyard from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm a child. Have it any  way you want. But I'm going back to  my own apartment, where I should have  lived in the first place. But no, I  got to listen to you and move here.  All right. If you want to live with  me, Anne, okay. But the sign outside  will say "Mr. Stew Smith" and you'll  have to be "Mrs. Stew Smith" or there's  nothing doing. No more Anne Schuyler's  husbandВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his bag all packed by this time.  He snaps it shut viciously, lifts it  off the chair, picks up his hat, and  notices Mrs. Schuyler staring open-mouthed  at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and here's some more news for you.  You can take your red room, your green  room, your left wing and your right  wing, and you know what you can do with  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes by Mrs. Schuyler and Anne,  exiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew and Gallagher appear, coming through  the iron gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew and Gallagher move off down  the street, a ragged old panhandler  comes wheedling up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, could you spare a dime for  a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew is struck by a sudden idea as he  regards the bum intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee? How would you like to be a Knight  of the Garter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew raises one foot, then the other,  and quickly removes the solid gold garters  which he presses into the bum's surprised  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, my man - with those you  can eat for a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away, leaving the bum staring  dazedly at the luxurious pair of garters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew and Gallagher pass the Camera  and go down the street, arm in arm.  As they get past the Camera, Stew is  seen to square his shoulders and throw  out his chest. He shakes first one leg,  and then the other, as if he were throwing  off shackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew and Gallagher moving along. Gallagher  has a peculiar expression as she glances  at Stew. She has been deeply affected  by the scene she has just witnessed.  Stew's face is very thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry too much about it,  Stew. She'll see it your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not worrying about her - I'm  worrying about that second act curtain,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher stares at him, realizing he  is thinking more about the play than  his split-up with his wife. Then she  breaks into a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you're just a first-class chump!  You just staged a scene that would play  like a million dollars! How about that  declaration of independence for the  second act curtain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew stops stock still and stares at  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an idea, Gallagher - a great  idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher happily links her arm in his  and again they move down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: CLOSE SHOT OF NAME PLATE OVER  DOORBELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 217. INT. STEW'S APARTMENT - DAY - MED.  FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inexpensive but comfortable. Stew is  in his shirtsleeves. A battered old  typewriter stands on the table with  a sheet of blank paper in it. Stew is  seated in a chair before it, and is  picking out the letters, typing. He  pauses, running up the roller to regard  what he has written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, in a little apron, is frying  some ham and eggs. She looks up as she  sees Stew from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about my breakfast? How do you expect  me to ring a curtain down on an empty  stomach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be ready in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind that. If you can't get my  breakfast ready - and can't get here  on time in the morning - then you can  go get yourself another job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry. Just get the breakfast,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 219. INT. STEW'S LIVING ROOM - MED.  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the hall door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stew opens the door. It reveals Dexter  Grayson in the little hallway, immaculately  clad, as usual. Stew regards him in  frank surprise for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you know why I cameВ—?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have no idea - unless some of  the silver-ware is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely, sit down. If I had known you  were coming, I would have thrown you  up a waffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson sits stiffly on one of the Grand  Rapids chairs. Stew remains standing,  and waits silently for Grayson to speak.  Grayson clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne asked me to come and see you about  the divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants me to arrange the financial  settlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Grayson, I've got 106 bucks and  75 cents in the bank. Now Anne can have  any part of that she wants, but she'd  better hurry because I'm spending it  awfully fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't seem to understand. Anne doesn't  expect anything from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher. Overcome by curiosity at  the sound of voices, she leaves the  frying eggs and goes quietly to the  doorway and peeks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should like to know how much you  would want toВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Do I get from you that  she wants to pay me alimony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew starts advancing nervously toward  him. Grayson, a bit alarmed, rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what I told you about that  twentieth crack? All right, you've just  made it. Before you go unconscious I  want you to get this through your nut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unconscious. You know, when you don't  know anything. Your natural state. There  are some people - you can't buy their  self-respect for a bucket of shekels  - well, I happen to be one of those  guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing kitchen door open a crack. Gallagher's  eyes are glistening as she watches and  listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think. Let me do all the thinking.  Now you go back to that Schuyler outfit  and tell them that I didn't marry that  dame for her dough and I don't want  any of her dough now. I was too poor  to buy her a wedding present when we  got married, so I'm giving her a divorce  for a wedding present. Now, stand up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grayson does so, completely intimidated  by Stew's manner. Stew grabs him by  the lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now for that twentieth crackВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew punches Grayson on chin and knocks  him through the open door into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew thrusts his hands into his pockets  and walks thoughtfully back to the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew standing staring down at the typewriter.  He is still flushed with anger. Suddenly  a thought strikes him, and his face  breaks into a broad grin. He sits down  quickly, and begins pounding away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher enters from the kitchen, carrying  a platter of ham and eggs and a coffee  pot. She sets them on a small table  and this is spread with a cloth. Then  she crosses over to Stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, that guy just dropped by  to give us a great opening for the third  act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit at the little table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the idea he gave you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stew dives into the ham and eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a swell idea, Gallagher. How's  this? The wife's family lawyer comes  to see the kid, see - to talk over the  divorce. Then this guy insults the poor  but honest boy by offering him alimony  - so the kid gets sore, socks the lawyer  in the nose and throws him out. How's  that for the beginning of the third  act, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, from now on the play will be easy.  All you have to do is bring the wife  back, have her say she's sorry, and  then your play's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at Gallagher with a peculiar  expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vehemently - as he scoops out some  melon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Do you think I'm  going to let that guy go back to his  wife? Not on your life. He's got to  go to the other girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She almost drops her coffee cup in a  wild gleam of hope as she looks back  at him. Gallagher tries hard to keep  her voice steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 232. MED. CLOSE SHOT OF THE TWO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little O'Brien girl, of course -  the one you suggested in the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's ridiculous! You can't make  a sudden change like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, what are you going to do  - tell me how to write a play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always loved the girl, but he was  such a sap he didn't have sense enough  to tell her. Well, that's all right  - we can fix that. He will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: go to the little O'Brien girl, and -  here, I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, and comes around  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher watches him a bit uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the little O'Brien gal and  he says to her - in some pretty words  of some kind - something that you can  write - he'll sayВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, I'm sorry. I've been a fool  all my life. I've always loved you,  only I didn't have sense enough to see  it. As quick as I can get a divorce  from my wife, I want you to marry me.  Then she'll look at him that way - yeah  - then they'll embrace, or something  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he'll kiss her, or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To demonstrate the point, Stew takes  her in his arms and kisses her. They  hold the kiss longer than is justified.  Stew is swept away by his sudden emotion  and clings to her desperately, while  Gallagher's arms instinctively go around  his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher chokes back tears that persist  in coming. She stifles a sob. Stew folds  her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Gallagher? What's  the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher buries her face in his shoulders.
